Right. I've been speculating a bit if you weren't aware before; I just like talking science. Anyway, since your particles have kinetic energy beforehand, they also have the velocity as in the equation. Once the particles "lose" their mass, kinetic energy is lost as a consequence. But it's due to the loss of mass rather than velocity. You most likely retain the velocity and instantaneously accelerate as light does, since you essentially now have the same properties as a photon.

Temperature is technically the measure of the average kinetic energy of a particle or substance. Basically, the matter that makes up the universe is constantly vibrating, and the energy with which it vibrates is defined by its temperature. So, since your particles already have kinetic energy because you aren't at absolute zero (that is, the complete lack of kinetic energy or temperature), you may begin travelling at the speed of light once you are somehow removed from the Higgs field.

We don't know! There are theories that postulate that the Higgs Boson has spin 0, 1, or 2. The Standard Model mostly predicts that the Higgs is spinless (ie spin 0) but some non-standard models suggest otherwise.
